perturbation.original_text: "Affiliate" With respect to any Party to this Agreement shall mean any company, corporation, firm, individual or other entity which Controls, is Controlled by or is under common Control with such Party to this Agreement for only so long as such Control exists;
perturbation.changed_text: "Affiliate" With respect to any Party to this Agreement shall mean any vaguely related company, corporation, firm, individual or other entity with some association to such Party to this Agreement for only so long as such association exists;
perturbation.explanation: The original definition uses 'Controls, is Controlled by or is under common Control' which has a specific legal and financial meaning. Changing the definition to 'any vaguely related company...with some association' introduces ambiguity. This undermines the purpose of defining affiliates, which is to clearly delineate entities with specific influence or ownership ties.
perturbation.law_explanation: The modified definition introduces uncertainty by replacing the clear criterion of 'control' with vague terms like 'vaguely related' and 'some association.' This directly contradicts the definition of affiliate under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 (17 CFR § 230.405), which requires 'control' (the power to direct management and policies) to establish affiliation. The change could allow parties to exploit loopholes by claiming or denying affiliate status based on subjective interpretations, affecting compliance with securities laws.

CFR Table of Popular Names prev | next § 230.405 Definitions of terms. Unless the context otherwise requires, all terms used in §§ 230.400 to 230.494, inclusive, or in the forms for registration have the same meanings as in the Act and in the general rules and regulations . In addition, the following definitions apply, unless the context otherwise requires: Affiliate. An affiliate of, or person affiliated with, a specified person, is a person that directly, or indirectly through one or more intermediaries, controls or is controlled by, or is under common control with, the person specified. Amount. The term amount, when used in regard to securities, means the principal amount if relating to evidences of indebtedness, the number of shares if relating to shares , and the number of units if relating to any other kind of security . Associate. The term associate, when used to indicate a relationship with any person, means (1) a corporation or organization (other than the registrant or a majority-owned subsidiary of the registrant) of which such person is an officer or partner or is, directly or indirectly, the beneficial owner of 10 percent or more of any class of equity securities, (2) any trust or other estate in which such person has a substantial beneficial interest or as to which such person serves as trustee or in a similar capacity, and (3) any relative or spouse of such person, or any relative of such spouse, who has the same home as such person or who is a director or officer of the registrant or any of its parents or subsidiaries. Automatic shelf registration statement. The term automatic shelf registration statement means a registration statement filed on Form S-3, Form F-3, or Form N-2 ( § 239.13 , § 239.33 , or §§ 239.14 and 274.11a-1 of this chapter) by

perturbation.original_text: "Applicable Laws" Shall mean all laws, rules and regulations regarding the manufacture, packaging, labeling, import, export, storage, distribution, representation, promotion, marketing and sale of the Products including but not limited to the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act of 1938, as amended ("FD&C Act") and the Controlled Substances Act, as amended (21 U.S.C. §801 et seq.), or as defined in attendant regulations promulgated under authorities granted by the FD&C Act, together with any equivalent laws, rules, regulations, codes or guidelines having effect in any jurisdiction in the Territory;
perturbation.changed_text: "Applicable Laws" Shall mean some suggestions or recommendations about the manufacture, packaging, labeling, import, export, storage, distribution, representation, promotion, marketing and sale of the Products, or guidelines that parties may choose to follow, that may influence the contract.
perturbation.explanation: The change replaces explicit legally binding statutes with suggestions and recommendations, which undermines the enforceability and compliance requirements of the contract.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act
perturbation.law_explanation: The modified definition directly contradicts the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (21 U.S.C. § 301 et seq.) by treating legally mandated regulations as optional guidelines. The FD&C Act imposes strict requirements on the manufacturing, labeling, and distribution of drugs and devices. By redefining 'Applicable Laws' to encompass only suggestions, the contract fails to ensure compliance with these mandatory legal standards, rendering the agreement unenforceable and potentially exposing parties to legal penalties for non-compliance with the FD&C Act.

perturbation.original_text: "Confidential Information" Means all confidential information, data and materials in whatever form disclosed by or on behalf of one Party or its Affiliates to the other Party or its Affiliates including, without limitation, the terms of this Agreement, data, formulae, unpublished patent disclosures, processes, protocols, marketing studies, sales information, specifications and know-how, (and, in the case of EKR's Confidential Information, EKR's marketing plans and EKR's sales forecasts), but excluding information which either Party can establish by written documentation: (i) at the time of disclosure, is in the public domain or is public knowledge; (ii) after disclosure, becomes part of the public domain by publication, except by breach of any obligation of confidentiality by a Party hereto or an Affiliate of such Party; (iii) was already in its possession at the time of its receipt and was not acquired directly or indirectly from the other Party or its Affiliates; or (iv) received from Third Parties who were lawfully entitled to disclose such information;
perturbation.changed_text: "Confidential Information" Means what each Party considers it to be, as long as they mark the document with the word 'confidential' regardless of its nature or availability to the public, with no exclusions, creating an unlimited interpretation of what qualifies as such.
perturbation.explanation: The initial definition provides specific criteria and exceptions, whereas the modified version lets each party subjectively designate anything as confidential. This ignores public domain status, prior knowledge, and lawful third-party disclosures, conflicting with established legal principles concerning trade secrets and confidential information.
perturbation.law_citation: Varies by State (e.g., California Civil Code § 3426)
perturbation.law_explanation: The modified definition conflicts with the Uniform Trade Secrets Act (UTSA), which defines a trade secret as information that (a) derives independent economic value from not being generally known and (b) is subject to reasonable efforts to maintain its secrecy. The change removes the requirement that the information has independent economic value and allows parties to designate publicly available information as 'confidential' simply by marking it as such. This contradicts the UTSA's requirement for genuine secrecy and economic value, potentially leading to the wrongful assertion of trade secret claims over non-confidential information.
